thread.title: Trains, tuk-tuks and Tibetan dumplings: snapshots of India – in pictures
thread.title_full: Trains, tuk-tuks and Tibetan dumplings: snapshots of India – in pictures

author: Moritz Peters
title: Trains, tuk-tuks and Tibetan dumplings: snapshots of India – in pictures
text:
Trains, tuk-tuks and Tibetan dumplings: snapshots of India Trains, tuk-tuks and Tibetan dumplings: snapshots of India View more sharing options Share on Messenger Close 
Amid epic rail journeys and the bustle of a city at night, photographer Moritz Peters found time to snap – and savour the food – at his favourite local restaurant Moritz Peters Wednesday 22 March 2017 13.09 GMT Getting into the routine I’m a photographer based in Hamburg, but currently exploring India. More than 22 million Indians travel by train every day. There is probably no better way to experience Indian railways than taking an 18-hour ride across the country in “sleeper class”.• Follow Mortiz on Instagram • Follow Guardian Travel on Instagram , use the tag #guardiantravelsnaps Three-wheeled adventures Delhi nights are full of honking and spotlights with auto rickshaws (tuk-tuks) filling the streets. Sometimes a whole bunch of passengers will be stuffed into the small space behind the driver; these three-wheelers are a staple of transportation in the city. Tucking in to momo in Darjeeling Darjeeling, close to the Nepalese border, is a good place to try momo: steamed Tibetan dumplings filled with meat, cheese or veg. I visited this man’s little restaurant almost every day. Topics
